fields.question: A refugee is a person who voluntary decides to move across an international border or within a State away from their habitual place of residence.
fields.help_text: A refugee is a person who has been forced to flee his or her country because of persecution, war, or violence and most likely cannot return home or is afraid to do so. A refugee has a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership in a particular social group.

fields.question: A refugee is a person who has been forced to flee their country because of persecution, war, or violence.
fields.help_text: A refugee is a person who has been forced to flee his/her country because of persecution, war, or violence for reasons of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership in a particular social group. Typically refugees cannot return home or are afraid to do so. They are protected by international law and are eligible to receive many types of aid.

fields.question: An asylum seeker is a migrant who has applied for citizenship in a country different from his/her origin country.
fields.help_text: An asylum seeker is a person who has fled his/her own country and has applied for asylum – the right to be recognized as a refugee and receive legal protection and material assistance. An asylum seeker must demonstrate that his or her fear of persecution in his or her home country is well-founded.

fields.question: A stateless person is someone who is not a citizen of any country.
fields.help_text: A person can become stateless due to a variety of reasons, including sovereign, legal, technical or administrative decisions or oversights. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights underlines that “Everyone has the right to a nationality.”
